pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces the automatic labeling of PRs.  The script is written in Lean and is used in CI.

Even though the PR appears very long, the actual code is only about 100 lines long.  The rest is taken by
* documentation;
* a whole file that simply adds the heuristic from [this Zulip post](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Auto-label.20PR.20topics/near/462530813) for labeling Mathlib PRs;
* a very extensive and verbose test file;
* a CI workflow that is mostly copied from the `new-contributor` workflow.

A very strong reason, in my opinion, to prefer this code to the shell-based one, is maintainability and extensibility.

Right now, the script only adds a label if exactly one applicable label is available.  This is very conservative, but the expectation is that it may change in the future.  As more elaborate heuristics may be developed, the Lean-script should adapt much more easily than the bash script.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5b7e9c4107](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15938/commits/5b7e9c4107d6bb0fb0d94cca78be455f9f59ee57)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Autolabels.EnvExtension`|1|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Autolabels.Labels` `Mathlib.Tactic`|2|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Label`
`+ addAllLabels`
`+ findLabel?`
`+ formatIdsToDirs`
`+ getLast`
`+ labelsToFiles`
`+ produceLabels`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

@adomani I'm pretty sure the glue code in the .yml file can be rewritten as a Lean script. Would you like me to do so?

(I will try to get to reviewing this PR; I think it's great to have this automation. But life/admin is catching up with me, so I don't want to promise any swift review.)

> Should this take the size of the git diff into account, to "weigh" the labels if there are multiple candidates? Or maybe that's better left to a follow-up version.

I intentionally went for a minimally invasive heuristic that would only label a PR when it was (hopefully) uncontroversial.  I am slightly more in favour of seeing how this minimalistic setup works.

If it ends up being the case that people feel like the auto-labels should be added more aggressively, it will be easy to add more and more heuristics to the mix.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.
Could you explain the design more either here or on zulip? I don't understand why an environment extension would be involved at all here.

Re the environment extension: I thought that they were quite "light", especially when they are basically not imported anywhere, as should be the case here.  It seemed to give an easy user experience, managing in the background all that is needed: keeping track of what has been defined and producing a well-formatted output.

I'm happy with a different proposal, though.
I have a counterproposal not using env. extensions, which might be cleaner. Might only create a PR with it tomorrow, so let me add "WIP" for the moment.

I've created a modified version at

- [ ] #17062

which does not use any env extensions and seems to be simpler. Only one of the two should be merged.
I'm closing this PR in favour of #17062 which is about to be merged :D
Should this take the size of the git diff into account, to "weigh" the labels if there are multiple candidates? Or maybe that's better left to a follow-up version.
Should this take the size of the git diff into account, to "weigh" the labels if there are multiple candidates? Or maybe that's better left to a follow-up version.
Jon, thank you so much for the review: I addressed your comments, mostly adding comments to the PR!

LGTM

maintainer merge

```suggestion
It uses the paths to check if any of the labels in the environment are applicable.
```
Is this sorting alphabetically?
Yes, I think so: the keys in `grouped` are `String`s, so `Prod.fst` returns an array of `String`s and then `qsort` uses `<` on `String`s which is alphabetical.
The name does not match the command.
I added a comment.  The point is that the command only needs `Lean.Elab.Command`, but `cache` can only `get` files in `Mathlib` (or so I think!).

This approach feels a bit hacky.

I have a few questions about this step, to which I think the explanation could be added as comments here:

- the `printf >>` hack is to avoid the noise on building normally, right?
- what's the reason to do 'lake build' twice? Has that also to do with the output?
- do you even need `produce_labels!` or are you just `sed`ing for the output of `produce_labels`?

* Yes, appending those lines is just to avoid noise in a regular build (comment added).
* The first run gets saved in the CI logs, so it helps with debugging (comment added).
* `produce_labels!` is only for debugging, the variable `labels` does not see the presence of `produce_labels!`.
This seems outdated, given that the CI actually uses `produce_labels`.
Rephrased!
This makes no sense, there is no notion of "cache" for `Lean.Elab.Command`. It is all in the `lean` binary!
Ah, great!  So, I ~~'ll~~ removed this step!
Could you use `tee` to avoid running twice?
I used `tee`, but I honestly find it less clear.
What's less clear about it? Looks good to me.
I'm not a big fan of these redirections, but I agree that this is almost as straightforward as it gets! ðŸ˜Š
What does `--` signify here? I don't understand.

Maybe one of the following notation is more intuitive?

```
* `Label.label : String`; the Github label
* Label.label (String): the Github label
```
Jon's interpretation is indeed what I had in mind, but it looks like it was confusing.  I simply remove `-- ...`, since the source code is right below anyway.

pullRequest.title: feat: add autolabeling of PRs
